segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Smoke from hundreds of wildfires in Canada is triggering air quality alerts throughout the U.S.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Skylines from Maine to Maryland to Minnesota are gray and smoggy.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: And in some places, the air quality warnings include the warning to stay inside.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: We wanted to better understand what's happening here and why, so we called Peter DiCarlo,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: an associate professor in the Department of Environmental Health and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Good morning, Professor.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Good morning.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: So what is it about the conditions right now that have caused this round of wildfires to affect so many people so far away?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: Well, there's a couple of things.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: The season has been pretty dry already.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: And then the fact that we're getting hit in the U.S. is because there's a couple weather systems

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: that are essentially channeling the smoke from those Canadian wildfires through Pennsylvania

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: into the mid-Atlantic and the northeast and kind of just dropping the smoke there.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: So what is it in this haze that makes it harmful?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: And I'm assuming it is harmful.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: It is.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: It is.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: The levels outside right now in Baltimore are considered unhealthy.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: And most of that is due to what's called particulate matter, which are tiny particles, microscopic, smaller than the width of your hair,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: that can get into your lungs and impact your respiratory system, your cardiovascular system,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: and even your neurological, your brain.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: What makes this particularly harmful?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Is it the volume of particulate?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Is it something in particular?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: You know, what is it exactly?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Can you just drill down on that a little bit more?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: Yeah.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: So the concentration of particulate matter, I was looking at some of the monitors that we have,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: was reaching levels of what are, in science speak, 150 micrograms per meter cubed,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: which is more than 10 times what the annual average should be,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: and about four times higher than what you're supposed to have on a 24-hour average.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: And so the concentrations of these particles in the air are just much, much, much higher than we typically see,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: and exposure to those high levels can lead to a host of health problems.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: And who is most vulnerable?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: I noticed that in New York City, for example, they're canceling outdoor activities,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: and so here it is in the early days of summer and they have to keep all the kids inside.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: So who tends to be vulnerable in a situation like this?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: It's the youngest.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: So children, obviously, whose bodies are still developing,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: the elderly who are, you know, their bodies are more in decline

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: and they're more susceptible to the health impacts of breathing the poor air quality.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: And then people who have pre-existing health conditions,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: people with respiratory conditions or heart conditions,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: can be triggered by high levels of air pollution.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Could this get worse?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: That's a good question.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: I mean, I think if, in some areas it's much worse than others,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: and it just depends on kind of where the smoke is concentrated.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: I think New York has some of the higher concentrations right now,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: but that's going to change as that air moves away from the New York area.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: But over the course of the next few days,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: we will see different areas being hit at different times with the highest concentrations.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: I was going to ask you about that.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: Unless more fires start burning,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: I don't expect the concentrations to go up too much higher.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: I was going to ask you how, and you started to answer this,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: but how much longer could this last?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Forgive me if I'm asking you to speculate, but what do you think?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: Well, I think the fires are going to burn for a little bit longer,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: but the key for us in the U.S. is the weather system changing.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: And so right now it's kind of the weather systems that are pulling that air

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: into our mid-Atlantic and northeast region.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: As those weather systems change and shift,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: we'll see that smoke going elsewhere and not impact us in this region as much.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: And so I think that's going to be the defining factor.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: And I think the next couple days we're going to see a shift in that weather pattern

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: and start to push the smoke away from where we are.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: And finally, with the impacts of climate change, we are seeing more wildfires.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Will we be seeing more of these kinds of wide-ranging air quality consequences or circumstances?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: I mean, that is one of the predictions for climate change looking into the future.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: The fire season is starting earlier and lasting longer,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: and we're seeing more frequent fires.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: So, yeah, this is probably something that we'll be seeing more frequently.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: This tends to be much more of an issue in the western U.S.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: So the eastern U.S. getting hit right now is a little bit new.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: But, yeah, I think with climate change moving forward,

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: this is something that is going to happen more frequently.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: That's Peter DiCarlo, Associate Professor in the Department of Environmental Health and Engineering

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: at Johns Hopkins University.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.text: Professor DiCarlo, thanks so much for joining us and sharing this expertise with us.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.text: Thank you for having me.
